importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The 2013 study, a peer-reviewed analysis, attempted to assess a correlation between infant acetaminophen use and autism, but did not establish causation or examine actual drug administration.
The 2015 Danish study found a statistically increased risk of autism in circumcised boys, though it did not examine acetaminophen use and had methodological limitations.
A 2025 preprint from WPLab, not peer-reviewed, claimed acetaminophen triggers autism and was cited by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., despite lacking scientific validation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period saw the publication of two studies that were cited by Kennedy as suggesting a link between circumcision, acetaminophen, and autism, though both were methodologically flawed and non-causal.

keyTakeAways: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. falsely claimed there is a link between autism and circumcision, citing two studies that only show a weak correlation and do not establish causation.
Neither the 2013 nor the 2015 study actually examined acetaminophen use or found evidence that the drug causes autism.
The 2025 WPLab preprint, which Kennedy referenced, has not been peer-reviewed and is based on a narrative claim that does not reflect scientific consensus.
The 2013 study was an exploratory analysis and used circumcision as a proxy for acetaminophen use, without confirming whether the drug was administered.
The 2015 Danish study found a modest increase in autism risk among circumcised boys, but sample sizes were extremely small and results were not robust or generalizable.
Experts emphasize that decades of research show acetaminophen is safe for infants when used appropriately under medical guidance, and no credible evidence links it to autism.
The WPLab study and Kennedy’s statements are criticized for misrepresenting the studies and promoting a causal narrative unsupported by rigorous scientific evidence.

namedEntities.name: Robert F Kennedy Jr
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: United States Health and Human Services Secretary
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He made public claims linking autism to circumcision and acetaminophen, which experts and scientists have challenged as unfounded and misleading.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is cited as having previously made similar speculative claims about acetaminophen and autism, drawing a parallel to Kennedy’s current assertions and highlighting a broader pattern of misinformation.

namedEntities.name: Acetaminophen
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is at the center of the false claim made by Kennedy that it causes autism, despite extensive scientific evidence showing it is safe when used as directed.

namedEntities.name: Circumcision
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Surgical removal of the foreskin of the penis
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is falsely linked to autism in Kennedy’s claims, though no robust evidence supports such a connection, and it is typically an elective procedure for cultural or religious reasons.

namedEntities.name: 2013 Study
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A peer-reviewed epidemiological study examining population-level correlations between acetaminophen use and autism
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was cited by Kennedy as evidence of a link between autism and circumcision, but it only found a weak association and explicitly stated no causal inference was intended.

namedEntities.name: 2015 Danish Study
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A study on circumcised boys and autism diagnosis rates in Denmark
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It found a modest increase in autism risk among circumcised boys, but had small sample sizes, limited data, and did not examine acetaminophen use.

namedEntities.name: WPLab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A North Carolina-based company promoting a link between acetaminophen and autism
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It authored a 2025 preprint that was cited by Kennedy and claims acetaminophen 'triggers' autism, though the paper is unpeer-reviewed and contradicts scientific consensus.

namedEntities.name: William Parker
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CEO of WPLab and retired Duke University associate professor
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has been in frequent contact with Robert F. Kennedy Jr., raising concerns about a potential influence on Kennedy’s public statements on autism and medication.

namedEntities.name: Helen Tager-Flusberg
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professor emerita at Boston University and founder of the Coalition of Autism Scientists
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is cited as an expert who critiques the methodology and limitations of the cited studies, emphasizing that correlation does not equal causation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: United States Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. made false claims linking autism to circumcision and acetaminophen, citing two flawed studies from 2013 and 2015. Experts clarify that neither study established causation, had significant methodological limitations—including small sample sizes and lack of data on acetaminophen use—and both explicitly cautioned against drawing causal conclusions. A 2025 preprint from WPLab, not peer-reviewed and promoted by a company with ties to Kennedy, falsely asserts that acetaminophen triggers autism. Decades of research confirm that acetaminophen is safe for infants when used as recommended. The article underscores the danger of misrepresenting scientific studies and highlights the importance of peer review, data transparency, and scientific consensus in public health discourse.
title: Fact-checking RFK Jr’s false claim linking autism to circumcision
